thread.title: Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven
thread.title_full: Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven

title: Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven
text:
Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven We preview the Redskins' fantasy match up for week seven. Next up: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Post to Facebook Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven We preview the Redskins' fantasy match up for week seven. Next up: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers.  //on.wusa9.com/1RWSD63   Join the Conversation To   Start 'Em, Sit 'Em: Redskins fantasy week seven Sam C. LaPaille, WUSA9 5:31 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Oct 6, 2014; Landover, MD, USA; A general view the Washington Redskins logo on the field prior to the game against the Seattle Seahawks at FedEx Field. Mandatory Credit: Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Geoff Burke, Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
WASHINGTON (WUSA9) -- The Washington Redskins (2-4) are set to take on the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (2-3) Sunday afternoon at FedEx Field. The Redskins are coming off a loss to the New York Jets in week six which saw the Redskins lead 13-10 at half, only to fall apart in the second half en route to a 34-20 loss. The Bucs are fresh off their bye week. 
Here's who to start and who to sit based on the match up against Tampa Bay. 
Start 'Em: WR's Pierre Garcon and Jamison Crowder 
With DeSean Jackson expected to miss another game and TE Jordan Reed returning from a concussion and other nagging injuries, Garcon and Crowder figure to be the go-to guys for QB Kirk Cousins on Sunday afternoon. And although Tampa Bay defends the pass well (202.4 YPG, 4th in NFL) they give up the fifth-most points to opposing fantasy wide receivers (26.6 PPG). 
Oct 4, 2015; Landover, MD, USA; Washington Redskins wide receiver Pierre Garcon (88) stiff-arms Philadelphia Eagles cornerback Nolan Carroll (23) while running with the ball in the third quarter at FedEx Field. The Redskins won 23-20. Mandatory Credit: Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Geoff Burke, Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports) 
Don't expect Garcon or Crowder to go wild against Tampa Bay, especially with Cousins struggling thus far in 2015, but the duo should see the majority of Cousins' targets. So if you're in a squeeze due to bye weeks or injuries, consider plugging Garcon or Crowder (especially in PPR leagues) to your fantasy lineup. 
Sep 20, 2015; Landover, MD, USA; Washington Redskins wide receiver Jamison Crowder (80) returns a punt against the St. Louis Rams during the first half at FedEx Field. Mandatory Credit: Brad Mills-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Brad Mills, Brad Mills-USA TODAY Sports) 
Don't expect either of them to go off for 12 catches, 140 yards and a touchdown due to Cousins' inconsistency, but the two could combine for those numbers versus Tampa Bay on Sunday. 
Sit 'Em: RB Alfred Morris 
It's time to hang it up on Morris unfortunately. The former bell cow of Washington's backfield has been turned into a mere afterthought this season. Morris hasn't been able to find the endzone once in 2015 and even when he was the feature back against the Jets in week six due to a Matt Jones injury, Morris squeaked out 21 yards on 11 carries. 
Sep 24, 2015; East Rutherford, NJ, USA; Washington Redskins running back Alfred Morris (46) is stopped by New York Giants strong safety Brandon Meriweather (22) and New York Giants defensive end Cullen Jenkins (99) during first half at MetLife Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Noah K. Murray-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Noah K. Murray, Noah K. Murray-USA TODAY Sports) 
With Jones expected to suit up on Sunday for the Burgundy and Gold, it becomes exceedingly difficult to predict Morris' value (if he has any left at all). Some people will hold onto the fact that Morris has rushed for 1,000-plus yards in each of his past three seasons, but it just isn't there for Morris this year. Whether it's Jay Gruden's play calling, the emergence of Matt Jones or some other reason, Morris is simply not the fantasy-lock he used to be. 
If you exclude Morris' 25-carry, 121-yard performance in week one against the Miami Dolphins, Morris has carried the ball 60 times for only 176 yards, which comes out to 2.93 yards per carry. Translation: Sit Morris if you haven't dropped him already.
